Caption: Fig. 1. Example of a data-driven video generated by a financial analysis using DataClips. Snapshot images illustrate the content of the video using 9 different clips: animated text, bar chart and line chart depicting the history of sales and salient events, pictograph and bar chart comparing production and sales, and unit pictograph, bar chart and donut chart illustrating sales during promotion.

Fig. 2. Annotated screenshot of DataClips tool interface: a) saved clip sequences, b) clip preview and sequencing panel, c) the clip library panel, d) clip configuration panel, e) import new data, f) clear all clips in preview/sequencing panel, g) category of clips for filling pictographs, h) data configuration options and corresponding input boxes, and i) helper images including numbered items corresponding to the input boxes, j) visual and animation configuration options and corresponding input fields.

Fig. 3. Taxonomy of clip types as a function of visualization types (rows) and animation types (columns). Icons and descriptions inside cells show one example implementation for each type.

Fig. 6. Annotation clips: (a) male and female icon embellishments above bars, (b) line chart with an- notated value and reference lines, (c) bar chart with highlight, and (d) US map with arrow annota- tion for a given state.

Fig. 5. Screenshot of the eight visualization type supported by DataClips. On the top row are standard charts: (a) Line chart, (b) Bar, (c) Donut, and (d) Map; and on the bottom row are pictograph-based representations: (e) Tally Pictograph, (f) Tally Pictograph-Comparison, (g) Colored Pictographs, and (h) Filled Pictographs.
